description: pfSense is a popular open source firewall solution that has many of the same features as some of the enterprise security appliances offered by many of the leading security appliance vendors.  It’s full feature set is provided free of charge.  This series was designed to introduce to our viewers the pfSense solution, demonstrate many of its features and provide some of the most essential configuration guidance to someone desiring to get pfSense working in their environment.
name: pfSense
subtitle: pfSense Build 2.2.2

episodes.description: pfSense is a popular open source firewall solution that has many of the same features as some of the enterprise security appliances offered by many of the leading security appliance vendors. It’s full feature set is provided free of charge. This series was designed to introduce to our viewers the pfSense solution, demonstrate many of its features and provide some of the most essential configuration guidance to someone desiring to get pfSense working in their environment.
episodes.title: pfSense Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:06.022
[SOUND] Welcome to the ITProTV

2
00:00:06.022 --> 00:00:12.040
pfSense Text Skill series.

3
00:00:12.040 --> 00:00:16.180
In this series of episodes, we're gonna
be taking a look at the pfSense firewall.

4
00:00:16.180 --> 00:00:19.190
And how we can implement that
in our homes and businesses.

5
00:00:19.190 --> 00:00:22.780
And really get a lot of great
functionality out of a firewall system.

6
00:00:22.780 --> 00:00:26.810
That is feature by feature,
a great competitor with the big

7
00:00:26.810 --> 00:00:30.350
commercial vendors out there like
Cisco and Juniper and those guys.

8
00:00:30.350 --> 00:00:34.130
>> The nice thing about the pfSense
firewall is really for the open-source

9
00:00:34.130 --> 00:00:37.480
crowd and for everybody else that's
trying to look for all the features.

10
00:00:37.480 --> 00:00:41.360
But you don't want to keep adding in and
spending more and more money.

11
00:00:41.360 --> 00:00:43.750
You gonna see that pfSense
really is a way to go and

12
00:00:43.750 --> 00:00:45.655
really a nice feature set for us.

13
00:00:45.655 --> 00:00:48.690
>> Ronnie, I know you've bumped into this,
I bumped into it to where

14
00:00:48.690 --> 00:00:52.190
you go to a business and
you start implementing a Cisco ASA.

15
00:00:52.190 --> 00:00:55.070
And then you find some feature you
wanna use and you're like oh shoot,

16
00:00:55.070 --> 00:00:57.640
I've gotta upgrade to the 50 user license.

17
00:00:57.640 --> 00:00:59.330
Or the unlimited user license,

18
00:00:59.330 --> 00:01:04.250
or the security plus license just to
get more than two interfaces working.

19
00:01:04.250 --> 00:01:06.785
And it's really frustrating and
really expensive.

20
00:01:06.785 --> 00:01:08.268
PfSense on the other hand,

21
00:01:08.268 --> 00:01:12.800
open-source firewall part if you
download it free from their website.

22
00:01:12.800 --> 00:01:15.380
And all of it's functionality
works out of the box.

23
00:01:15.380 --> 00:01:18.570
That's the way they make money,
is they make money off of support tickets.

24
00:01:18.570 --> 00:01:21.710
If you want commercial support
from pfSense [INAUDIBLE],

25
00:01:21.710 --> 00:01:23.540
call them on the phone and
they help you out.

26
00:01:23.540 --> 00:01:24.810
Well, you have to pay for that.

27
00:01:24.810 --> 00:01:28.016
But if you want community support and
to set it up yourself,

28
00:01:28.016 --> 00:01:29.694
they don't charge you a dime.

29
00:01:29.694 --> 00:01:33.370
It doesn't matter if you have 1 user or
10,000 users, they don't care.

30
00:01:33.370 --> 00:01:34.490
It will flow right through.

31
00:01:34.490 --> 00:01:36.040
It is a great firewall system.

32
00:01:36.040 --> 00:01:37.650
I've used it in a number of locations.

33
00:01:37.650 --> 00:01:38.580
Ron, you use it too.

34
00:01:38.580 --> 00:01:39.320
>> I do, yeah.

35
00:01:39.320 --> 00:01:42.248
I've used it in a couple of
different locations that really,

36
00:01:42.248 --> 00:01:44.969
it made more sense to go with
the features that we needed.

37
00:01:44.969 --> 00:01:48.520
And so, I'm only willing to spend this
much amount of money to be able to do so.

38
00:01:48.520 --> 00:01:52.485
And I said, well you're actually taking
a look at doing a Cisco firewall.

39
00:01:52.485 --> 00:01:54.950
And you're gonna have to do exactly
what Don was talking about.

40
00:01:54.950 --> 00:01:56.380
You keep upgrading,
all of a sudden they're like,

41
00:01:56.380 --> 00:01:58.128
that's a little bit out
of our price range.

42
00:01:58.128 --> 00:01:59.320
Recommending a pfSense and

43
00:01:59.320 --> 00:02:03.490
saying hey, as long as you have
a computer that can pretty much run it.

44
00:02:03.490 --> 00:02:07.120
We can actually go ahead and implement
this and have a full feature firewall set.

45
00:02:07.120 --> 00:02:10.340
>> A couple of neat features about pfSense
that will make you want to choose it as

46
00:02:10.340 --> 00:02:11.410
a firewall.

47
00:02:11.410 --> 00:02:12.460
It is free right?

48
00:02:12.460 --> 00:02:13.310
That's pretty cool.

49
00:02:13.310 --> 00:02:16.740
>> A big one
>> It runs on top of FreeBSD, which is

50
00:02:16.740 --> 00:02:21.090
a Unix-based operating system that's
designed to run on standard hardware.

51
00:02:21.090 --> 00:02:23.270
So if you wanna buy a firewall appliance,

52
00:02:23.270 --> 00:02:25.210
something as dedicated as a firewall,
you can.

53
00:02:25.210 --> 00:02:27.560
And you can buy them with pfSense on them.

54
00:02:27.560 --> 00:02:32.300
Or if you want, you can just take
a regular PC, a server, a one use server.

55
00:02:32.300 --> 00:02:34.050
Or even a desktop, you have laying around.

56
00:02:34.050 --> 00:02:35.960
I've done it on old laptops before.

57
00:02:35.960 --> 00:02:39.430
And you can throw pfSense right on there,
cuz it supports standard hardware.

58
00:02:39.430 --> 00:02:43.140
64-bit and 32-bit,
you can throw it on there.

59
00:02:43.140 --> 00:02:47.090
It's really pretty flexible for
that and that's something that's nice.

60
00:02:47.090 --> 00:02:50.930
Another nice feature is
the web-based user interface, right?

61
00:02:50.930 --> 00:02:53.732
We keep singling out Cisco,
which I feel a little bad about it.

62
00:02:53.732 --> 00:02:55.770
>> [LAUGH]
>> Cuz Cisco does make great equipment.

63
00:02:55.770 --> 00:02:59.870
But if you wanna manage a Cisco firewall,
you've either got the command-line.

64
00:02:59.870 --> 00:03:04.816
Or you've got their Java standalone
interface for which is really unpleasant.

65
00:03:04.816 --> 00:03:07.030
I mean, just running Java is unpleasant.

66
00:03:07.030 --> 00:03:08.380
With pfSense, it's just a webpage.

67
00:03:08.380 --> 00:03:10.280
Browse this webpage,
you punch in your config.

68
00:03:10.280 --> 00:03:12.810
You do have the command-line also,
if you wanna go that route.

69
00:03:12.810 --> 00:03:16.270
It's very flexible,
lots of possibilities in there.

70
00:03:16.270 --> 00:03:18.100
It's a great solution.

71
00:03:18.100 --> 00:03:20.470
>> Unlike [LAUGH], again picking on Cisco,
>> [LAUGH]

72
00:03:20.470 --> 00:03:21.120
>> A little bit, but

73
00:03:21.120 --> 00:03:24.300
unlike setting up that
initial Cisco firewall,

74
00:03:24.300 --> 00:03:27.084
being able to just install the pfSense.

75
00:03:27.084 --> 00:03:29.750
And then at the very end once
it's installed, it says, hey,

76
00:03:29.750 --> 00:03:31.970
this is how you connect and
begin to configure it.

77
00:03:31.970 --> 00:03:34.140
You can have the pfSense
firewall actually up and

78
00:03:34.140 --> 00:03:36.600
running, probably within half an hour.

79
00:03:36.600 --> 00:03:38.310
>> Easy.
>> And now you're actually just

80
00:03:38.310 --> 00:03:39.710
tweaking all your settings.

81
00:03:39.710 --> 00:03:42.780
And so the ease of usage,
the ability for someone to say,

82
00:03:42.780 --> 00:03:44.730
all right,
I can feel comfortable with this.

83
00:03:44.730 --> 00:03:46.770
It's incredibly easy in pfSense.

84
00:03:46.770 --> 00:03:49.120
>> All right, so
what are we gonna cover in this series?

85
00:03:49.120 --> 00:03:51.120
Well, if you stay tuned to
watch our pfSense series.

86
00:03:51.120 --> 00:03:55.552
We're gonna show how to get a copy of
pfSense, how to install it on hardware.

87
00:03:55.552 --> 00:03:57.520
Cuz there's are a couple of
different methods you can go.

88
00:03:57.520 --> 00:04:00.340
We'll walk through each of
the different ways to get it installed.

89
00:04:00.340 --> 00:04:01.420
And then once it's up and running,

90
00:04:01.420 --> 00:04:04.290
we're gonna run through
some basic routing setup.

91
00:04:04.290 --> 00:04:06.340
We'll show how to do
firewall filter rules.

92
00:04:06.340 --> 00:04:09.110
Cuz it is a firewall,
you probably wanna do that.

93
00:04:09.110 --> 00:04:12.320
We'll also take a look at Network adress
translation, which is pretty important,

94
00:04:12.320 --> 00:04:13.970
as well as port forwarding.

95
00:04:13.970 --> 00:04:16.335
And we're gonna take a look at VPN setups.

96
00:04:16.335 --> 00:04:19.030
Site-to-site VPNs for connecting offices,

97
00:04:19.030 --> 00:04:23.510
as well as just regular remote access
VPNs to allow your traveling users.

98
00:04:23.510 --> 00:04:26.620
Your people that are out in the field
to be able to connect back in and

99
00:04:26.620 --> 00:04:27.930
work with the system.

100
00:04:27.930 --> 00:04:30.970
It's all functionality that's
baked right into pfSense.

101
00:04:32.110 --> 00:04:33.190
Towards the end of the series,

102
00:04:33.190 --> 00:04:36.250
we're gonna take a look at some of
the packages we can install in pfSense.

103
00:04:36.250 --> 00:04:39.370
Now this is something that sets
pfSense aside from other firewalls.

104
00:04:39.370 --> 00:04:42.130
The packages, it's third-party
software that we can load and

105
00:04:42.130 --> 00:04:43.870
run right from our firewall.

106
00:04:43.870 --> 00:04:46.760
And there's a wide range of
packages that are out there.

107
00:04:46.760 --> 00:04:51.685
From advanced reporting services,
to proxy and web filtering services.

108
00:04:51.685 --> 00:04:54.560
There's all sorts of
neat little gadgets and

109
00:04:54.560 --> 00:04:58.150
stuff that you can install there to make
your firewall do some really cool stuff.

110
00:04:58.150 --> 00:05:00.540
That you normally would have
to have a separate device for.

111
00:05:00.540 --> 00:05:01.910
Here we can kind of wrap it all together.

112
00:05:02.940 --> 00:05:06.230
So a lot of different choices,
a lot of different flexibility.

113
00:05:06.230 --> 00:05:08.107
It's a great system to use.

114
00:05:08.107 --> 00:05:10.786
So definitely something that
you'll wanna check out,

115
00:05:10.786 --> 00:05:12.500
if that sounds interesting to you.

116
00:05:12.500 --> 00:05:15.670
Sounds like something you wanna learn more
about, then you're in the right place.

117
00:05:15.670 --> 00:05:19.160
Stay tuned cuz we've got our
pfSense series coming up.

118
00:05:19.160 --> 00:05:22.890
If you're a die hard Cisco fan and that's
the route you wanna go or Juniper or

119
00:05:22.890 --> 00:05:23.850
the other guys.

120
00:05:23.850 --> 00:05:27.230
Well, the concepts that we cover
over these next several episodes,

121
00:05:27.230 --> 00:05:28.940
they really apply to any firewall, right?

122
00:05:28.940 --> 00:05:31.070
All the firewalls basically work the same.

123
00:05:31.070 --> 00:05:32.540
It's just the implementation is different.

124
00:05:32.540 --> 00:05:34.290
The commands, the web interface.

125
00:05:34.290 --> 00:05:38.140
But remember at ITProTV, you have access
to the whole library with your account.

126
00:05:38.140 --> 00:05:41.280
So you can jump over to the Cisco
shows and check those out.

127
00:05:41.280 --> 00:05:43.710
Or whatever other resource it
is that you wanna use there.

128
00:05:43.710 --> 00:05:46.430
But if you wanna learn about pfSense,
you're in the right place.

129
00:05:46.430 --> 00:05:49.176
Stay tuned,
we've got pfSense episodes coming up.

130
00:05:49.176 --> 00:05:55.539
>> [MUSIC]
